with the use of the given programming language, you can get the top n most frequent words from a particular line and print out their frequency.

2. What are the basic steps involved in text summarization?
- Segment the text into sentences
- Tokenize the sentences into words
- Extract features from the words
- Rank the sentences based on scored by the features
- Select the n best sentences

3. Can we use word embeddings instead of features for text summarization?
- Yes, word embeddings can be used as a feature for text summarization.

4. What are the features used in text summarization using word embeddings?
- The word embeddings can be trained on a large corpus of text data and represent the semantic meaning of words. They can capture important semantic relationships and dependencies between words.

5. How can we calculate the significance of a feature in text summarization?
- The significance of a feature can be calculated using a statistical test like ANOVA or t-test. For example, we can calculate the p-value of the t-test to determine if the difference between the means of two groups is statistically significant.

6. What are some common techniques for text summarization?
- Common techniques for text summarization include extractive and abstractive summarization. For extractive summarization, we select the most important sentences in the text and summarize them, while for abstractive summarization, we generate new sentences that capture the essence of the text.

7. How does text summarization task differ from text classification?
- Text summarization task differs from text classification in that the summarization is done by selecting the important sentences, while text classification is done by assigning a label to the text.

8. What is the significance of using topic modeling for text summarization?
- Topic modeling is important for text summarization because it can help summarize the text by highlighting the most important topics and

data.sampled:
: "I'm an Asian American and I play the violin."
"Sure, what do you want to talk about?"
I am grateful, as usual. That evening we sit in my room and have a long talk. As we talk, I feel myself open up for the first time in a long while.

> "I think it was because I played the violin that I saw the world in such a beautiful way. I remember one time at the park, we were playing 'Liebestraumes' together. You know that song? (points to a song from Johann Sebastian Bach's Well-Tempered Clavier) She was playing it so beautifully, like a wisp of music floating across water. I thought how the human heart must feel like that, going on and on, in a beautiful and constant motion, like the strings of my violin, and how that must be the truest, most genuine form of expression."

The woman was thrilled and told me I should keep practicing my violin because she thought I had a really good ability to play the violin. I thanked her, although I wasn't as into playing the violin as much as I was before. I had developed other interests and was more interested in other hobbies such as sports.

Routing can be done in a number of ways, including:

* Simple round-robin: /0/0
* Single-hit (pre-fetching) with fixed time out: /100/100
* Asynchronous, adaptive pre-fetching with fixed time out: /200/200
* Optimized pre-fetching with variable time out: /300/300.

In this case, each route can be seen as a queue of HTTP GET requests with the parameters of the request indicating which queue it should be added to. The first route, for example, would be added to the queue in the order that the routes are specified, with the other queues being held in reserve in the event of a route overloading.

In practice, I would probably define the routes based on the structure of the API surface, such as /users, /orders, etc., or possibly based on some external indicator (e.g., if the URL includes a customer identifier, route it to the corresponding /users endpoint instead of /v1/users).",

,
a client of mine wants to send push notifications to iOS devices, but he does not have any apple developer membership.
However, he has a web app. Can he still send push notifications to iPads and iPhones?

A: Yes. For your own, non-third-party apps you can use the following services:

http://ipn.io, free for 30 notification per day
http://pushkit.withgoogle.com/, free for 5000 daily requests
https://firebase.google.com/products/push, free for up to 2000 daily requests

For 3rd party apps you can use the following:

https:// monetize.appodeal.com/, the same price as App Store
https://adpush.io/ pricing is based on the number of daily unique iOS installs

For the web, you can use:

https://www.appstoreconnect.apple.com/ for free
http:// monetize.appodeal.com/ with some conditions
http://adpush.io/ free for up to 1000 daily requests

You must have an Apple ID to use any of those services
Please note: Apple does not allow for commercial push notifications without explicit authorization in the app Store; I believe that you can get around that by providing a web app to access these notifications (so that the user has a "link" to the app, rather than actually installing it on their device)

A: Yes. You can't access a paid API without your client getting an Apple developer account. Also, you can't use iAd or IAP without an account.

A: AFAIK you can't send notifications to iOS devices without a developer account.
The only way you could send notifications and not use one of the paid services would be building and maintaining your own server and then communicating with it from an Application that is installed on

I think I understand now, I think you would like to know a way to iterate through `my_list` such as this:
```python
for number in my_list:
    print(number)
```

# no

Alternatively:
```python
my_list = [1,2,3]

    print(element)
```

If that is the case, there are other ways to iterate through lists in python.

```python
my_list = [1,2,3]

    print(element)
```

```python
my_list = [1,2,3]
```

```python
my_list = [1,2,3]
```

my_list = list(iter(my_list))

data.sampled:
the following method is called on a UIView element:
- (void)setUserInteractionEnabled:(BOOL)enabled {
    self.userInteractionEnabled = enabled;
}

How could the view's size change the functionality of this method?

A: If the view has a frame with an origin other than (0.0, 0.0), but the value of userInteractionEnabled is NO - the view will be treated as if the user interaction is enabled (the origin of the frame does not matter).
: If the view has a frame with an origin other than (0.0, 0.0), and userInteractionEnabled is YES, you get the effect of user interaction being disabled as the frame origin is relative to the view's superview, and the view will not receive events.

A: If enabled="YES" the view will be sent touch events instead of user interaction events, and not participate in the responder chain when you respond to them.
If enabled="NO" the view will be ignored when you respond to touch events, not participating in the responder chain.
Both conditions may trigger user interaction events, but the view will have different responder status and will behave according to it.
: If the enabled='NO', but the view is not laid-out fully or is the right edge of aSuperView's bounds, it gets one of the "special" user interaction flags (e.g. interactive="YES").
A view like that will receive the user interaction events, but won't respond to them, e.g. you can't add other subviews with interactive = YES in this view.
If the view is fully laid-out, it loses this flag, as it is not the right edge of aSuperView's view hierarchy, so it doesn't interact with its events.

, has been developed to support this. If a user is currently registered and logged in to the system, they can access their account information by clicking the "Account" link from any page.

For example, if a user with the login name "john" is currently logged in, they would see the following account information displayed on the "Account" page:
```php
Account Information
    ID: 1234
    Username: john
    Firstname: John
    Lastname: Doe
```
Here, the "ID" column represents the unique identifier for the account, and the "Username" and "Firstname" columns provide the user's name associated with the account. Finally, the "Lastname" column represents the user's last name.

To display an account's information, you can simply pass the ID value along with the Username to the "Account" page using a GET request. For example, if john's ID value was 1234, you could display his account information by sending the following URL to the user:
```python
http://example.com/account.php?id=1234
```

On the "Account" page, you can then retrieve the Username associated with the account by querying the database using the ID value. Here's an example PHP code snippet for retrieving a user's username from the database using their ID value:
```php
$id = // retrieve the ID value from the GET request parameters
$username = // query the database to retrieve the associated username for the given ID value

// display the user's username on the "Account" page
echo $username;
```

This code would retrieve the Username associated with the specified ID value from the database and display it on the "Account" page.

I hope this helps explain how the API works! Let me know if you have any further questions or concerns."

In the first example, the first person uses the second person form of the verb tense. In the second example, the second person form of the verb is replaced by the third person form. This is a common feature of English and is often called the "singular you" form or "plural you" form.

data.sampled:
: Is there any way to write a file without any data in it in python?
What is the simplest way of writing 0's to a file in python?

A: Using the in-built open() function, you can open a file in write-only mode, and can create it if it doesn't exist yet:
with open("foo.txt","w") as outf:
    outf.write("")

or with other methods (I think the most Pythonic way would be with open()):
import os

with open(filename, "wb") as outf:
    outf.write("")

This can be done if you want to create the file, with minimal lines. Here is a method to replace your 0's with 0x00s to make it easier to get rid of afterwords:
import string

with open("foo.txt","wb") as outf:
     outf.write(chr(0) * (len(newline)//8) )

Note: when opening the file, you need to specify "w" or "wb".

A: In Python 3.2 and up, you can use bytes object with the flush method:
with open("somefile", "w") as outf:
  outf.write(b"")

In older versions of Python, you can use b on a string, which creates a bytes object with the same data:
with open("somefile", "w") as outf:
  outf.write(b"")

For a file that already exists, you should open it in binary mode:
with open("somefile", "rb") as outf:
  outf.write(b"")

The b prefix is short for bytearray, which is more Pythonic.

        print(i)

The output of this code would be:

```
0
2
4
6
8
```

if yes, then please share the link to the resource where I can learn more about the technique.

2- how does it work?

A: There are a number of ways.
One common technique is to use WiFi networks to get the user's location. There is a number of projects which use this method of getting an accurate location, which was the aim in the original question to learn more about the technique used.
One such example for such a project would be to look here.
Another example using the same protocol is to look here.

A: There are many techniques to get your users' location without GPS as you have found from the above website. The technique that I would like to share with you and also the one I have implemented in my iPhone app is by using the cell tower/ WiFi network/ GSM tower. This is not the most accurate location based location as it only takes into consideration the general direction that a signal from a tower has been emitted from. However it can get good results to within some 20 yards to 100 yards or so depending on the strength of the signal. But there are other techniques such as your own network type that I can share with the user in the app to give the most accurate location. You can get some very good tutorials on it by searching around the web. The basic technique has been presented in many places already in terms of how to do a cell and WiFi tower lookup to get cell tower position or get WiFi network information or get the user's cell tower/ cellular information. Also you can find more detail on how to do it specifically for the iPhone app by looking at Apple's Developer documentation. 
Good luck!
  How to implement iOS Cell tower and WiFi network location in Xcode 6.x using Swift and ARC

data.sampled:
.NET Class ```string```
It seems like it is only possible to create a string from a hexadecimal code.

Is there a way to use the unicode directly within a string variable as long as its only one character?

i.e.:

`char` *hex* = `U+00A3` (á)
`string` = "á"

What I want (in C#):

`string` = "á"

*

*Or what's the smallest input I need to create an empty string with this symbol?:

`emptyString` = ""*U+00A3*

A: The string is immutable, so you can't change it. You could create a new variable, and re-assign the string if you like.
string _str = string.Empty;
_str = _str + 'á';

...

or
string _str = string.Empty;
_str += 'a';

...

or
char _tstr = 'a';
string _str = new stringBuilder(1).ToString();
_str = new stringBuilder(_str).Append(new char[] { _tstr }).ToString();

...

or
string _str = "a";
_str = new string(_str, 1); // will append a second character to the string

...

It is better to use these code blocks in context where the input string can be modified. The new string can then be written to a stream, or assigned to _output_string. 
I personally hate it when code blocks are used in a loop as there will be a small chance for a bug due to mis-predicting the state of the string. It can also be improved by using a "foreach" so that you can create this block of code only on the
